columns.text: In this example, we need to see whether a change in credit policy is good for Bismark Co. company or not.

To decide if we will change the policy, we need to calculate the present value of the cash flow with new policy and the cost of switching. The switch should be made if the sum of PV of cash flow with new policy and the cost of switching is greater than zero. So, we need to calculate the NPV of switching, and if it is greater than zero, then the switch will be profitable.

Let's first identify the given data in a problem:

| Data        |Designation       | Amount |
| ------------- |:-------------:| -----:|
| Current price per unit     | P| \$350|
| Credit price (the no-discount price)     | P$^{\prime}$     |\$368|
| Current quantity sold per priod | Q      |    \$25,000 |
|Percentage of credit sales that go uncollected|$\pi$|0.03|
|Percentage discount allowed for cash customers|d||
|Required rate of return|R|0.025|

Currently, Bismark Co. sells $Q=25,000$ units at a price of $P=\$350$. The company wants to introduce a new credit policy and increase prices to $P^{\prime}=\$368$ on credit sales. The cash price will remain at $\$350$, co company  effectively allowing a discount of $\frac{\$368-\$350}{\$368}=\frac{18}{368}=0.0489$ or $4.89$  for cash. So, $d=0.0489$.

Formula to find the NPV of the switch is 
$$\begin{align*}
NPV&=-PQ+P^{\prime}Q\cdot \frac{(d-\pi)}{R}
\end{align*}$$ 
Replace the known values we get
$$\begin{align*}
NPV&=-\$350\cdot 25,000+\$368\cdot 25,000\cdot \frac{(0.0489-0.03)}{0.025}\\
&=-\$8,750,000+\$9,200,000\cdot \frac{0.0189}{0.025}\\
&=-\$8,750,000+\$9,200,000\cdot 0.756\\
&=-\$8,750,000+\$6,955,200\\
&=-1,794,800
\end{align*}$$ 
Since the NPV of the change is negative, company should not change its credit policy.
